message_1: A group of students is creating a Latin square using the digits 1 to 9, where each digit can only appear once in each row and column. How many different Latin squares can they create?
message_2:
The number of different Latin squares of order n (i.e., n x n squares) is not a simple formula, and it is not known for all values of n. However, the number of Latin squares of order 9 (using the digits 1 to 9) has been calculated.

The number of different 9x9 Latin squares is 552,475,149,615,689,041.

So, the group of students can create 552,475,149,615,689,041 different Latin squares using the digits 1 to 9.
